definitions.a: A traditional software development model where each phase (requirements, design, implementation, testing, deployment, and maintenance) is completed sequentially.
definitions.b: A methodology focused on iterative and incremental development, where requirements and solutions evolve through collaboration between self-organizing cross-functional teams.
definitions.c: An ad hoc approach to maintaining software. It is a fire-fighting approach waiting for the problem to occur and then trying to fix it as quickly as possible.
definitions.d: A simple working system implementing only a few basic features is built, thereafter many successive iterations/ versions are implemented and delivered to the customer.

definitions.a: The process of restructuring code, while not changing its original functionality.
definitions.b: Refers to designing solutions that continue to function efficiently with a growing number of users.
definitions.c: The implied cost incurred when businesses do not fix problems that will affect them in the future.
definitions.d: The traces in the code that indicates a deeper problem in the application or codebase.
